title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The findings are outlined in Section 2. The Congress finds a shortage of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. There is a dire shortage of adoptive parents, with many children waiting for adoption. The increase in adoptions from foster care has created a need for post-adoption services. One Church, One Child is a national foster care and adoption ministry providing services for at-risk children and adoptive families. Despite its success, the program receives limited federal funding. The One Church, One Child program and similar programs have limited federal funding. A federally-funded grant program supporting the recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on this concept will benefit abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified parents. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS are added to Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to support the recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, benefiting abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified parents. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through public, private, and faith-based organizations. Eligible entities include state or local governments, community-based organizations, and faith-based organizations. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities, including state or local governments, community-based organizations, and faith-based organizations, to establish or expand programs for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents. Applicants must submit an application with project descriptions, coordination plans with state and local entities, and details of services to be provided. The entity receiving grants must coordinate with State and local entities for foster parent recruitment, maintain records for oversight, and adhere to necessary audits. The term 'State' includes various regions, and there are limitations on appropriations. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate up to $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005 through 2009 for certain territories. Unused grant funds must be returned, and the Secretary can redistribute them to entities in need. Religious organizations must not discriminate when awarding grants. The Secretary can allocate up to $20,000,000 annually for specific territories from 2005 to 2009. Unused funds will be returned and redistributed. Religious organizations must not discriminate when awarding grants, and they are treated equally with other organizations under the Establishment Clause. Religious organizations cannot be forced to change their internal governance or remove religious symbols from their premises. Religious organizations receiving funds under this section must not alter their internal governance or remove religious symbols from their premises. Funds provided directly to these organizations cannot be used for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. They are subject to the same regulations as other nongovernmental organizations for fiscal accountability. The organization receiving funds must adhere to accounting principles and keep the funds separate from other accounts. SEC. 4. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Programs; Annual Report to Congress. Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act is further amended by adding a National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing post-placement support, technical assistance, training, and identifying best practices for grantees. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to provide technical assistance, training, and best practices for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, collecting data on program effectiveness, and assisting in report preparation. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to provide technical assistance, training, and best practices for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, collecting data on program effectiveness, and assisting in report preparation. A nationally recognized, nonprofit adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment organization selected through a competitive process will have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations interested in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization with a national reputation in working with faith-based and community organizations to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. The organization must have extensive experience in establishing programs based on the One Church, One Child model. Authorization of appropriations is limited to $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. Annual reports detailing the number of entities receiving grants and foster parents must be submitted to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. The organization must have experience with the One Church, One Child model. Annual reports must include the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents recruited, children placed, and program outcomes.
